subject: Re: Aesthetic Concerns for a new font.
msgSnippet: Kyudosha, Please upload the font to the file section if you have not done so already.  It would also be a good idea to upload your keyboard layout to the file
messageBody:
Kyudosha,

Please upload the font to the file section if you have not done so
already. It would also be a good idea to upload your keyboard
layout to the file section as well.

If possible, I would like for you to experiment with a keyboard
layout that might be more approachable by those fluent in English.

Shavian starts with the IPA conventions which is fine for those who
know the IPA conventions. ENgliS represents the shifted vowels
AEYOU as they are in the traditional orthography.

ace = As, me = mE, my=mY, most=mOst, use=Us or Uz
The short or stopped vowels are at=qt, edge=ej, itch=iC, all=ol,
pot=pct, up=up, hook=hvk. Schwa is short but it is also free:
ago=agO. hoop=hwp.

For more detail, see
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/schemes/englis-
short.html

Of course, I would like to see a variety of phonemic fonts use
ENgliS as the keyboard position. This would make building
converters that much easier to build. At the present time one has
to create dictionaries using a variety of different ASCII-IPAs
instead of just one.

For some prototype converters see
WebReformer
http://lismore.ccl.umist.ac.uk/cgi-bin/toby/web-page-
translation/spel.pl

Steve


--- "Jon Zuck" <jon@f...> wrote:

> Kyudosha,
>
> Thanks for creating a new font! And good luck. I designed Jerome
> two-and-a-half years ago just as to get SOMETHING out there for
the Read
> alphabet. I was hoping that a dozen other fonts would follow, as
with
> Shavian. Silly fonts, serious fonts, serif and sans-serif fonts,
movie
> poster styles, type styles, cursive styles, everything, like Steve
Bett
> and others did for the Shaw alphabet. But I lack the time and
graphic
> expertise.
>
> Thanks for stepping up to the plate. If you have any questions,
> concerns that I can help you with, let me know.
>
> PS, the only reason why I chose the keyboard layout I did was for
> consistency with the original Shaw alphabet. It seems that's no
longer
> needed, so have at it, and let us know how it's going!
>
> jon
>
>
>
>
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: kyudosha [mailto:kyudosha@y...]
> Sent: Tuesday, June 03, 2003 6:53 PM
> To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Aesthetic Concerns for a new font.
>
> Hello all. I am designing a replacement truetype font for Jerome.
> This new font (called KINGSLEY.TTF) will include (among other
things)
> a more intuitive keyboard layout based on a one-to-one conversion
> between the sounds of T.O. and Readscript, characters with standard
> stroke widths and joining points, and kerning pairs that provide
what
> I perceive to be the best representation of the way Readscript was
> meant to be written.
>
> For consistency's sake, I am currently going to be the only active
> developer until the font reaches a suitable beta release state,
but I
> would like the input and participation of all Readscript
enthusiasts
> in this endeavor, such that we can truely have a font written
> by-enthusiasts-for-enthusiasts and one that we can all have some
> amount of personal involvement and satisfaction in.
>
> There are, of course, stumbling blocks to be overcome and questions
> about standardization that need to be asked, so I have decided to
ask
> them here and now (even though the characters are only about
halfway
> finished).
>
> To kick things off, my first question to the quickscript community
> regards the joining of characters to letter #25/Roe.
>
> As is plainly seen, the character was designed with two joining
> points, both of which are incoming points and exist on the same
> x-plane. It shares the first of these properties with #22/May, and
> shares both of these properties with only one other character:
> #37/OUt. This introduces problems in font design when being
connected
> to by any characters that cross into the x-plane through or beyond
> both joining sites (i.e. #'s 3, 7, 10, 14, 26, 27). When examined
> further, however, one notes that most of these characters would
NEVER
> join to #25, except perhaps #7 or #27. I have noticed on page 13
of
> the Quickscript Manual that there seemes to be an extra character
#36
> in the example "mere" (27-36-25). Is this really #36, or one of
the
> "confusing linking strokes" that Read talks about? If it IS #36,
is
> this because of English pronunciation?
>
> Thanks, and I look forward to further input in participation in
this
> project
>
>
>
>
